Literature Review: The spin Seebeck effect (SSE) has emerged as a powerful tool for probing the fundamental properties of magnetic materials, including elementary excitations, static magnetic order, spin correlation, and spin transport. Since its discovery in 2008, the SSE has been extensively studied across a wide range of magnetic materials, from ferromagnets and ferrimagnets to antiferromagnets and paramagnets. This review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the recent progress in understanding the SSE and its applications as a sensitive probe of magnetic properties in solids. The SSE is characterized by the generation of a spin current in response to a temperature gradient in a magnetic material. This spin current can be detected electrically through the inverse spin Hall effect (ISHE) in a metallic contact. The ISHE converts the spin current into a charge current, which can be measured as a voltage. The relationship between the SSE and the ISHE has been well-established, and the combination of these effects has opened new avenues for studying spin dynamics and transport in magnetic materials (Uchida et al., 2008). ### Elementary Excitations One of the key aspects of the SSE is its sensitivity to the elementary excitations in magnetic materials. In ferromagnets, the primary excitations are magnons, which are quantized spin waves. The SSE voltage is strongly influenced by the magnon population and their dynamics. For example, in yttrium iron garnet (YIG), a model ferromagnetic insulator, the SSE has been shown to be proportional to the magnon density, providing a direct measure of the magnon population (Uchida et al., 2010). This relationship has been further explored in other ferromagnetic materials, such as nickel ferrite (NiFe2O4), where the SSE has been used to study the magnon dispersion and relaxation processes (Kehlberger et al., 2015). In antiferromagnets, the elementary excitations are more complex due to the presence of both acoustic and optical magnons. The SSE in antiferromagnets has been observed in materials such as MnF2 and NiO, where it has been linked to the dynamics of these magnons. The SSE in antiferromagnets can provide insights into the spin wave spectrum and the nature of the magnetic order (Shiomi et al., 2016). ### Static Magnetic Order The SSE is also sensitive to the static magnetic order in materials. In ferromagnets, the SSE voltage is typically positive, reflecting the alignment of spins in the same direction. In contrast, in antiferromagnets, the SSE can be either positive or negative, depending on the relative orientation of the sublattices. This property has been exploited to study the magnetic phase transitions in antiferromagnets, such as the NÃ©el transition in MnF2 (Shiomi et al., 2016). The SSE can also be used to detect the presence of magnetic domains and domain walls, which can significantly affect the spin transport properties of the material (Kehlberger et al., 2015). ### Spin Correlation Spin correlation plays a crucial role in the SSE, particularly in materials with strong spin fluctuations. In paramagnets, the SSE can be used to probe the short-range spin correlations that exist above the magnetic ordering temperature. For example, in the paramagnetic phase of YIG, the SSE has been observed to persist even at temperatures well above the Curie point, indicating the presence of correlated spin fluctuations (Uchida et al., 2010). Similarly, in quantum spin liquids, where long-range magnetic order is absent, the SSE can provide insights into the nature of the spin correlations and the dynamics of the spin excitations (Shiomi et al., 2016). ### Spin Transport The SSE is closely related to the spin transport properties of magnetic materials. The spin current generated by the SSE can be transported over long distances in materials with low spin relaxation rates, such as YIG. This property has been exploited in spin caloritronics, where the SSE is used to generate and manipulate spin currents for various applications, including spin logic devices and spin-based information processing (Uchida et al., 2008). The SSE has also been used to study the spin Seebeck length, which characterizes the distance over which the spin current can propagate before being converted into a charge current (Kehlberger et al., 2015). ### Nuclear Spin Seebeck Effect Recently, a new variant of the SSE, known as the nuclear spin Seebeck effect (NSSE), has been discovered. The NSSE involves the generation of a nuclear spin current in response to a temperature gradient. This effect has been observed in materials such as silicon and germanium, where the nuclear spins are coupled to the electronic spins through hyperfine interactions. The NSSE provides a unique opportunity to study the nuclear spin dynamics and the coupling between nuclear and electronic spins in solids (Shiomi et al., 2016). ### Conclusion In conclusion, the spin Seebeck effect has proven to be a versatile and powerful tool for probing the fundamental properties of magnetic materials. Its sensitivity to elementary excitations, static magnetic order, spin correlation, and spin transport makes it an invaluable technique for advancing our understanding of spin dynamics in solids. The recent discovery of the nuclear spin Seebeck effect further expands the scope of the SSE, opening new avenues for research in the field of spin caloritronics and beyond. As the field continues to evolve, the SSE is likely to play an increasingly important role in the development of novel spintronic devices and materials.
